pt: {sc}witty{/sc} {sc}humorous{/sc} {sc}facetious{/sc} {sc}jocular{/sc} {sc}jocose{/sc} mean provoking or intended to provoke laughter. {sc}witty{/sc} suggests cleverness and quickness of mind.
{sc}humorous{/sc} applies broadly to anything that evokes usually genial laughter and may contrast with {it}witty{/it} in suggesting whimsicality or eccentricity.
{sc}facetious{/sc} stresses a desire to produce laughter and may be derogatory in implying dubious or ill-timed attempts at wit or humor.
{sc}jocular{/sc} implies a usually habitual fondness for jesting and joking.
{sc}jocose{/sc} is somewhat less derogatory than {sc}facetious{/sc} in suggesting habitual waggishness or playfulness.

quotes.t: Nor was Liebling seriously asserting that his {qword}facetious{/qword} bit of investigation into Tin Pan Alley history constituted a refutation of Sartre's philosophy.
The portrait is good, the prose embroidered here with the {qword}facetious{/qword} parlance—is that the word?—of clubs.
… old ladies shrivelling to nothing in a forest of flowers and giant {qword}facetious{/qword} get-well cards …

et: borrowed from Middle French {it}facetieux, facecieux,{/it} from {it}facetie{/it} "joke, jesting remark" (borrowed from Latin {it}facētia, facētiae{/it} "cleverness, wit," in plural sense, "amusing things, jests") + {it}-eux{/it} (going back to Latin {it}-ōsus{/it} {et_link|-ous|-ous}) {ma}{mat|facetiae|}{/ma}
shortdef: joking or jesting often inappropriately : waggish
meant to be humorous or funny : not serious
